"For God so loved the world, that He gave His only begotten Son, that whoever believes in Him shall not perish, but have eternal life. For God did not send the Son into the world to judge the world, but that the world might be saved through Him. body:
All the evidence points towards those "other parts" being the authentic ones. Genesis was in fact almost certainly written *after* most of the prophets who referred to Sodom and Gomorrah being destroyed for brutality. Are these older witnesses really wrong against later scribes who couldn't even decide whether something was from God or the devil?

And I don't know if this was intentional or not, but your reply makes it sound like you think hospitality is a *bad* thing.

**But Jesus did not answer a word. So His disciples came and urged Him, “Send her away, for she keeps crying out after us.” 24 He answered, “ I was sent only to the lost sheep of the house of Israel.”
**
At the time Jesus was still trying to appeal to the Jews of Israel, who rejected him. The dispensation of Grace began after "the stoning of Steven" in Acts. God came to the Jews to be accepted as their King, and acted accordingly. They chose to crucify him, an extension of mercy was provided afterward, and then he came to us the Gentiles. 

I hope you will learn dispensationalism.

body:
Ok, you pick and choose what you consider scripture and have created your own Bible, this is why you have these errors.

Free will and the decisions of greedy and evil people can't be altered with probability. Their hearts were hard and they were going to reject Christ. God came to them in the way he promised, in the way that most glorified him, and he wasn't going to change this in order to appeal to the children of Israel. The Jews would have probably accepted a powerful and fearful ruler who promised them world conquest, riches, and high positions of status in the new world government. God doesn't conform to what people will accept or want.

Thanks for being honest and direct, it's an easier conversation than with people who ignore questions.

body:
I rejected Paul because Paul basically turned Christianity into some form of weird mix of Roman supremacy, Jewish supremacy, and Manifest Destiny bullshit whereby one is expected to slavishly obey the Roman bourgeoisie as long as it does not conflict with the protection of the chosenites......well, depending on who is speaking at the moment. There was a time when he pandered to some Germanics as well

It's as confusing as the whims of the Catholic Church. One moment the Church accepts (renamed) Nordic/Roman Pagan practices and holidays, another time it bans Joss-Sticks....the Catholic Church is as arbitrary and racist as the people who runs it. It got so bad to the point where everyone started to say "F U" to Catholicism to revert back to a saner form of Christianity, known as Protestanism. The only consistent about Paulism is that whichever race sits on the papal throne, dictates Catholic bias for the day. When it's the Romans, the Catholics are biased towards Romans. When it's the Germans, the Catholics are biased towards Germans.

Just look at that absolute shithole known as Catholic opinion of Jews, which ranged from "We must protect them, they are Jesus's chosen peoples and we are but adopted children" to "KILL THEM ALL. KILL THEM 109 TIMES"

Or look at the current pope and his bias towards libshits

How about the man himself? During his time, he walked around and made bullshit compromises here and there in order to Romanify the fucking Church while simultaneously preserving a little bit of Jewish old power. So basically the same shit as Manifest Destiny and your modern libshit pope. Paul served man more than any divine force. Seriously, have you even looked at his admonition against those who preserve the old law?
